Title: Getting Started with QR-Based Restaurant Management System API

Nodes.Text: API for browsing menu items and placing orders in a QR-based restaurant system.
The generated code depends on a few Ruby gems. The references to these gems are added in the gemspec file. The easiest way to resolve the dependencies, build the gem and install it is through Rake:

1. Install Rake if not already installed: `gem install rake`
  2. Install Bundler if not already installed: `gem install bundler`
  3. From terminal/cmd navigate to the root directory of the SDK.
  4. Invoke: `rake install`
Alternatively, you can build and install the gem manually:

1. From terminal/cmd navigate to the root directory of the SDK.
  2. Run the build command: `gem build qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api.gemspec`
  3. Run the install command: `gem install qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api-1.0.1.gem`

The following section explains how to use the qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api ruby gem in a new Rails project using RubyMine™. The basic workflow presented here is also applicable if you prefer using a different editor or IDE.
Close any existing projects in RubyMine™ by selecting `File -> Close Project`. Next, click on `Create New Project` to create a new project from scratch.

Nodes.AlternateText: Create a new project in RubyMine - Step 1

Nodes.Text: Next, provide `TestApp` as the project name, choose `Rails Application` as the project type, and click `OK`.

Nodes.AlternateText: Create a new Rails Application in RubyMine - Step 2

Nodes.Text: In the next dialog make sure that the correct Ruby SDK is being used (>= 2.6 and <= 3.2) and click `OK`.

Nodes.AlternateText: Create a new Rails Application in RubyMine - Step 3

Nodes.Text: In order to use the `qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api` gem in the new project we must add a gem reference. Locate the `Gemfile` in the Project Explorer window under the `TestApp` project node. The file contains references to all gems being used in the project. Here, add the reference to the library gem by adding the following line: `gem 'qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api', '1.0.1'`

Nodes.AlternateText: Add new reference to the Gemfile

Nodes.Text: Once the `TestApp` project is created, a folder named `controllers` will be visible in the *Project Explorer* under the following path: `TestApp > app > controllers`. Right click on this folder and select `New -> Run Rails Generator...`.

Nodes.AlternateText: Run Rails Generator on Controllers Folder

Nodes.Text: Selecting the said option will popup a small window where the generator names are displayed. Here, select the `controller` template.
Next, a popup window will ask you for a Controller name and included Actions. For controller name provide `Hello` and include an action named `Index` and click `OK`.
A new controller class named `HelloController` will be created in a file named `hello_controller.rb` containing a method named `Index`.

1. Add the `require 'qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api'` statement to require the gem in the controller file.
  2. Add the `include QrBasedRestaurantManagementSystemApi` statement to include the sdk module in the controller file.
  3. In the `Index` method, add code for initialization and a sample for its usage.
The following parameters are configurable for the API Client:

Data: The Faraday connection object passed by the SDK user for making requests
The Faraday adapter object passed by the SDK user for performing http requests

The value to use for connection timeout.
**Default: 30**

The number of times to retry an endpoint call if it fails.
**Default: 0**

The amount to multiply each successive retry's interval amount by in order to provide backoff.
**Default: 2**

A list of HTTP methods to retry.
**Default: %i[get put get put]**
The Http CallBack allows defining callables for pre and post API calls.
Optional proxy configuration to route HTTP requests through a proxy server.
The SDK logging configuration for API calls
The credential object for OAuth 2 Bearer token

Nodes.Text: The API client can be initialized as follows:

This API uses the following authentication schemes.
* [`bearerAuth (OAuth 2 Bearer token)`]($h/__auth_BearerAuth)
Documentation for accessing and setting credentials for bearerAuth.

Data: The OAuth 2.0 Access Token to use for API requests.

Nodes.Text: **Note:** Auth credentials can be set using named parameter for any of the above credentials (e.g. `access_token`) in the client initialization.
You must provide credentials in the client as shown in the following code snippet.

require 'qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api'
include QrBasedRestaurantManagementSystemApi

client = Client.new(
  bearer_auth_credentials: BearerAuthCredentials.new(
    access_token: 'AccessToken'
  )
)
This page can contain Tutorials/Guides/Changelogs or any information that API providers want to expose to their users besides what is auto-generated by Apimatic.

* [Menu]($e/Menu)
* [Order]($e/Order)
Endpoints for browsing menu items
An instance of the `MenuApi` class can be accessed from the API Client.
menu_api = client.menu

Nodes.Title: List Menu Items
Nodes.Name: list_menu_items
Nodes.Description: Returns the full list of menu items currently available for ordering.
Nodes.ResponseText: This method returns an [```ApiResponse```]($h/__additional_documentation/Utilities/ApiResponse) instance. The `data` property of this instance returns the response data which is of type [```MenuResponse```]($m/MenuResponse).

ReturnTypeExample.Text:
{
  "success": true,
  "count": 2,
  "data": [
    {
      "_id": "66cfe9b1f23a4a0012ab0001",
      "name": "Margherita Pizza",
      "description": "Classic pizza with tomato sauce, mozzarella, and basil",
      "price": 1199.0,
      "category": "Pizza",
      "image": "https://cdn.example.com/img/margherita.jpg",
      "isAvailable": true
    },
    {
      "_id": "66cfe9b1f23a4a0012ab0002",
      "name": "Chicken Biryani",
      "description": "Spiced rice with marinated chicken",
      "price": 899.0,
      "category": "Main",
      "image": "https://cdn.example.com/img/biryani.jpg",
      "isAvailable": true
    }
  ]
}

Nodes.Text: Endpoints for creating and viewing orders
An instance of the `OrderApi` class can be accessed from the API Client.
order_api = client.order

Nodes.Title: Place Order
Nodes.Name: place_order
Nodes.Description: Creates an order for the specified items and table.
Nodes.ResponseText: This method returns an [```ApiResponse```]($h/__additional_documentation/Utilities/ApiResponse) instance. The `data` property of this instance returns the response data which is of type [```OrderResponse```]($m/OrderResponse).

Parameters.Name: body
Parameters.Description: Order payload including items, table number, and customer details.

Response.Description:
Order placed successfully

This endpoint returns an [```ApiResponse```]($h/__additional_documentation/Utilities/ApiResponse) instance. The `data` property of this instance returns the response data which is of type [```OrderResponse```]($m/OrderResponse).

Nodes.Text: Represents the proxy server configurations for API calls.
Properties

Data: The port to connect to the proxy server.

CodeExamples.Title: Usage Example
CodeExamples.Text:
client = QrBasedRestaurantManagementSystemApi::Client.new(
 proxy_settings: ProxySettings.new(
    address: "http://localhost",
    port: 8888,
    username: 'user',
    password: 'pass'
  )
)

Nodes.Text: An abstract class for custom logger implementation.
Logger Methods

Data: Logs a message with a specified log level and additional parameters.

1. level (Integer): The log level of the message.
2. message (String): The message template to log.
3. params: (Hash): The parameters to include in the log message.

Nodes.Text: Usage Example
Client Initialization with Custom Logger
In order to provide custom logger implementation, the `AbstractLogger` class must be inherited so that you can override the `log` behavior.

require 'ougai'
require 'logger'

include QrBasedRestaurantManagementSystemApi


class CustomLogger < AbstractLogger
  def initialize
    @logger = Ougai::Logger.new($stdout)
  end
  def log(level, message, params)
    case level
    when Logger::INFO
      @logger.info(message, params)
    end
  end
end
Following is how the custom logger implementation can be injected in the SDK client.

require 'qr_based_restaurant_management_system_api'
include QrBasedRestaurantManagementSystemApi

client = Client.new(
  logging_configuration: LoggingConfiguration.new(
    logger: CustomLogger.new
  )
)
Represents the logging configuration for API calls.
Parameters

Data: Takes in your custom implementation of the abstract logger class here. **Default Implementation : `ConsoleLogger`**
Defines the log message severity available in ruby logging module (e.g., DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL, UNKNOWN5). **Default : `Logger::INFO`**
Toggles the global setting to mask sensitive HTTP headers in both requests and responses before logging, safeguarding confidential data. **Default : `true`**
The logging configuration for an API request.
The logging configuration for an API response.

Nodes.Text: Represents the logging configuration for API request.
Parameters

Data: Toggles the logging of the request body. **Default : `false`**
Toggles the logging of the request headers. **Default : `false`**
Includes only specified request headers in the log output. **Default : `[]`**
Excludes specified request headers from the log output. **Default : `[]`**
Logs specified request headers without masking, revealing their actual values. **Default : `[]`**
Toggles the inclusion of query parameters in the logged request path. **Default : `false`**

Nodes.Text: Represents the logging configuration for API response.
Parameters

Data: Toggles the logging of the response body. **Default : `false`**
Toggles the logging of the response headers. **Default : `false`**
Includes only specified response headers in the log output. **Default : `[]`**
Excludes specified request headers from the log output. **Default : `[]`**
Logs specified request headers without masking, revealing their actual values. **Default : `[]`**

Nodes.Text: Http response received.
Properties

Data: The status code returned by the server.
The reason phrase returned by the server.
The request that resulted in this response.

Nodes.Text: Represents a single Http Request.
Properties

Data: The HTTP method of the request.
The endpoint URL for the API request.
Request context for passing meta information about the request.

Nodes.Text: Represents the complete HTTP response received from the API.
Properties

Data: The HTTP status code of the response.
The reason phrase returned with the status code.
The raw response body as a string.
The parsed response data, if applicable.

CodeExamples.Title: Usage Example
CodeExamples.Text:
begin
  # Perform API request
  response = client.example_controller.example_endpoint(input)

  # Inspect response attributes
  puts "Status Code: #{response.status_code}"
  puts "Headers: #{response.headers}"
  puts "Parsed Data: #{response.data}"
rescue APIException => e
  puts "Caught APIException: #{e.message}"
end
